label: Federal Repository · Washington, D.C.
name: National Archives (NARA)
notes: Primary custodian of the JFK Assassination Records Collection under the JFK Records Act of 1992. Holds millions of pages from over 60 government agencies.

label: Federal Repository · NSA
name: NSA Historical Releases — JFK
notes: National Security Agency signals intelligence records declassified under the JFK Records Act transparency initiative.

label: Presidential Library · Boston, MA
name: John F. Kennedy Presidential Library
notes: Official presidential library housing Kennedy's personal papers, White House records, oral histories, and photographs from his administration.

label: Presidential Library · Austin, TX
name: Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library
notes: Holds records from the Johnson administration including Warren Commission materials, post-assassination transition files, and related correspondence.

label: Presidential Library · Ann Arbor, MI
name: Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library
notes: Contains Ford's files as a Warren Commission member, including working papers, interview notes, and correspondence during the 1964 investigation.

label: Independent Archive · Digital
name: Mary Ferrell Foundation
notes: Largest independent online repository of JFK assassination records. Hosts over 1.5 million digitized pages cross-referenced with the NARA collection.

label: University Archive · Hood College, MD
name: Harold Weisberg Archive
notes: Personal research archive of assassination critic Harold Weisberg. Contains correspondence, FOIA responses, and original investigative documents spanning four decades.

label: University Archive · Waco, TX
name: Baylor University Poage Library — JFK Collection
notes: Academic collection of materials related to the Kennedy assassination, including congressional records and regional Texas documents.

label: Independent Archive · Washington, D.C.
name: Assassination Archives and Research Center (AARC)
notes: Non-profit repository specializing in political assassination records. Holds unique materials obtained through FOIA and private donation since 1984.

label: Museum Archive · Dallas, TX
name: Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza
notes: Located in the former Texas School Book Depository. Maintains oral histories, photographs, and artifacts related to the assassination and its aftermath.

label: Independent Archive · Digital
name: The Black Vault — JFK Records
notes: FOIA-driven digital archive. Hosts thousands of declassified government documents obtained through independent records requests.

label: Independent Archive · Digital
name: History Matters
notes: Online archive of Warren Commission testimony, exhibits, and investigative records. Cross-referenced with HSCA and ARRB materials.

label: University Archive · Denton, TX
name: University of North Texas — JFK Portal
notes: Digitized Texas-based JFK materials from the UNT Texas History Portal, including Dallas-area news coverage and municipal records.

label: University Archive · Arlington, TX
name: University of Texas Arlington Libraries
notes: Special collections including regional Texas history materials pertaining to the Kennedy assassination and the Dallas political climate of 1963.

label: Municipal Archive · Dallas, TX
name: Dallas Municipal Archives
notes: City of Dallas government records including Dallas Police Department files, city council records, and official communications from November 1963.

label: Public Library · Dallas, TX
name: Dallas Public Library — History Division
notes: Holds local history materials, newspaper archives, and photographic collections documenting Dallas in November 1963.

label: University Archive · Medford, MA
name: Tufts University Tisch Library — JFK Collection
notes: Academic database access to the JFK Assassination Collection. Digitized primary sources available for scholarly research.

label: University Archive · Washington, D.C.
name: National Security Archive (GWU)
notes: George Washington University non-governmental research institute. Holds declassified CIA covert operations files and briefing books on the Kennedy assassination records.

label: Industrial · Dallas, TX
name: Texas Butchers Supply Company
notes: Privately owned company in Dallas where Ralph Leon Yates was employed as a refrigeration mechanic in 1963.

label: Federal Agency · Washington, D.C.
name: Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI)
notes: Domestic intelligence and security service of the United States. Conducted the primary initial investigation into the assassination under Director J. Edgar Hoover.

label: Municipal Police · Dallas, TX
name: Dallas Police Department (DPD)
notes: Local law enforcement agency responsible for the immediate crime scene investigation and the arrest of Lee Harvey Oswald.

label: Presidential Commission · 1963-1964
name: The Warren Commission
notes: President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. Established by LBJ to investigate the assassination. Concluded Oswald acted alone.

label: Congressional Committee · 1976-1979
name: House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA)
notes: U.S. House of Representatives committee established to investigate the assassinations of JFK and MLK. Concluded that JFK was 'probably assassinated as a result of a conspiracy'.

label: Senate Committee · 1975-1976
name: The Church Committee
notes: U.S. Senate Select Committee to Study Governmental Operations with Respect to Intelligence Activities. Investigated intelligence abuses by the CIA, FBI, IRS, and NSA.

label: Federal Agency · Langley, VA
name: Central Intelligence Agency (CIA)
notes: Foreign intelligence service of the U.S. government. Scrutinized for its surveillance of Oswald in Mexico City and potential knowledge of threats to the President.

label: Independent Agency · 1994-1998
name: Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB)
notes: Independent U.S. government agency created to oversee the release of government records related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

label: District DA · New Orleans, LA
name: New Orleans District Attorney's Office (NODA)
notes: The office of District Attorney Jim Garrison, which conducted the only criminal trial (State of Louisiana v. Clay Shaw) related to the assassination of President Kennedy.
